text: Your Friday Evening BriefingHere’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
Listen to ‘Rabbit Hole’What is the internet doing to us? Binge our latest series.
A Conversation on the ElectionTimes reporters hosted a discussion on Thursday with Julián Castro.

Portland Leaders Question Role of the Feds in Quelling UnrestFederal authorities said they would bring order to Portland, Ore., after weeks of protests there. Local leaders believe they are making things worse.Mayor Ted Wheeler said the federal response was “irresponsible” and asked for those deployed to stay inside federal buildings or leave the city.

Pentagon Sidesteps Trump to Ban the Confederate FlagIn a carefully worded memo, Defense Secretary Mark Esper listed the types of flags that are allowed to appear on bases worldwide. That flag does not fit.
A City Investigates Its Traumatic HistoryNearly a century after a massacre in Tulsa, Okla., the search for burial sites has finally broken ground.

U.S. Report Finds 18 States With ‘Red Zone’ OutbreaksThe states are mostly in the Sun Belt and make up more than a third of the nation. Some of them aren’t heeding recommendations to curb the spread.California’s governor announced rules that would force most schools to start the year with virtual learning. Here’s the latest.
See which treatments show the most promise

Janitors Have a Warning About the State of Cleaning in the U.S.Planes are wiped in under 10 minutes. Many custodians have to bring their own supplies. In a few cases, there’s not even hot water to wash their hands.

New York City Eases Into Phase 4 of Reopening, but Indoor Limits RemainThe city will allow some places to reopen outdoors on Monday, while many indoor activities, like restaurant dining, remain forbidden.
Inside Johnson & Johnson’s Nonstop Hunt for a Coronavirus VaccineIn Boston and in the Netherlands, scientists are racing to build a vaccine against the virus strangling the world.
Georgia Governor Sues Atlanta Mayor to Block Mask RulesThe clash between the two leaders has come at what may be the worst possible time in Georgia.
A Detailed Map of Who Is Wearing Masks in the U.S.The patterns from hundreds of thousands of survey respondents reflect partisanship, peer pressure and the footprint of the virus itself.

Ginsburg Says Her Cancer Has Returned, but She’s ‘Fully Able’ to WorkThe news from Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg led to speculation about an opening on the Supreme Court, as both parties make its future an election issue.
Jamaal Bowman, Insurgent Democrat, Defeats Eliot Engel in House PrimaryMr. Bowman defeated the 16-term incumbent in a race that pitted the Democratic establishment against the party’s left wing.
The Democrats Are Downsizing Their Convention to Almost NothingAn event that was once expected to draw 50,000 people to Milwaukee may now involve just 300, with plans still far from settled.
Several people involved in the hacking of prominent Twitter accounts described a pursuit of Bitcoin that spun out of control.
A FaceTime session with Larry after he was taken off the ventilator. Heather Sten for The New York Times
Cate Stetson and Ruth FriedmanThe Justice Department’s Shameful Rush to Federal ExecutionsThe push to impose the federal death penalty no matter the cost poses a grave threat to the rule of law.

A Father of 2 Boys Went to War. We Chronicled Their Lives for 10 Years.The costs of war are often tallied in troops lost or wounded, but there are other consequences that are harder to measure.

Christopher Nolan Says ‘Tenet’ Will Come Out This Summer. Should It?The director had hoped to aid struggling theater owners, but continuing to delay his blockbuster two weeks at a time may be prolonging their pain.
Social Programs Can Sometimes Turn a Profit for TaxpayersGovernment assistance can be expensive, but a new study shows that some programs more than pay for themselves.
